bibl.title: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, February 8, 1942

div1.p: Wood comments on Kelly's implication that Reed had difficulty getting Army approval to go to Johns Hopkins. She has been told that a medical officer in the Navy is also writing about Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, February 8, 1942

opener.dateline:
1338 19th St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
February 8, 1942

div1.p:
The photostats arrived, and I shall be very glad to turn them
over to you when I finish my work. I'll send them back to you
with all your material.

I'm sorry you didn't meet Col. Jones, the SG's librarian. He
is tall and handsome and nice - but you probably already knew
him.

I'm going to see Blossom and Granny soon. I talked to the Gen-
eral last week and he said if his mother was still feeling ill,
as she was for a couple of days, he would have me and his sister
out at his house some afternoon, otherwise I should call on them
at the hotel.

Taking your suggestion, I went down to Archives, and had quite
a busy day going through some material on Reed. It doesn't at
all bear out Kelly's implication that he had a tough time getting
the army to let him go to Johns Hopkins. I'm going to do further
searching and see if I can find any correspondence between
Reed and the SG or Adjutant General that indicates how and under
what circumstances he went there. In the correspondence I saw,
he asked for 4 months leave in July, 1892 to begin Sept. 1, and got
it, so tht he could study “practical medicine and surgery” (not
bacteriology) at Hopkins. Then on Octl 1 he asked for a trans-
fer to Baltimore, so tht he could take the full course, and four
days later it was granted. That certainly doesn't sound like
hard going to me, unless there is something missing which is per-
fectly possible, and even likely, according to Mr. Todd, the man
in charge. According to the reports, Reed spent a great part of
the summer of 1891 on examining boards, at West Point, Washington
and New York. He was in New York all of October and went from
there straight to Ft. Snelling, arriving November 7.

It was so nice to see you and Mrs. Hench, and I am so irked and
disappointed that I was out when you called again. I went to see
Dr. Howard a few days ago, and he told me that you had been to see
him - isn't he old, though. General Kean had to go back to the
hospital, but Mrs. Ireland tells me that he is all right again.
When I see Mrs. Blossom Reed I shall by all means ask her if I
may see the letters she let you copy, although I'm afraid it's
a little late to do me much good. It occurs to me to wonder if
Lazear's “little black notebook” could be buried somewhere at
Archives. I think I'll poke around a bit and see if I can turn
it up.

Thank you so much for coming to see me, and for your good sug-
gestions.

Did you know that some medical officer in the Navy is doing a job on Reed, too?
Mr. Todd didn't tell me who he is - only that he appears to be esp. interested
in his Ft. Snelley & St. Paul days.
